DOC.HEAD: Sakharov Buried Amid Academics, Soldiers
With AM-Sakharov, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The resting place of Nobel Peace Prize winner and human rights champion Andrei D. Sakharov is Vostryakovskoye Cemetery, Moscow's largest. It is a sprawling 19th century cemetery set amid pine trees in southwestern Moscow. Sakharov's coffin was lowered into a grave Monday in a plot beside that of his mother-in-law, Ruth Bonner. The cemetery is at the crossroads of the Borovskoye Highway and Moscow Ring Road at the city limit. Historically, it was the graveyard of the Vostryakovo village and became a Moscow city cemetery in 1932. It was expanded in 1963 to its current size of 370 acres. Among those buried in the cemetery are marshals, generals, academicians and honored Soviet citizens. It is divided into Russian and Jewish sections, and also contains graves of people of mixed nationalities. Mrs. Bonner was a Stalin-era political prisoner who died in Moscow at age 87 in 1987. Also nearby is the grave of Mrs. Bonner's son, Igor Alikhanov, an officer in the Soviet merchant marine who died in 1976 at the age of 49.
